title: Dublin Murders star says it’s important to remember time before #MeToo
text:
Dublin Murders star says it’s important to remember time before #MeToo (Picture: BBC)

Dublin Murders star Sarah Greene believes it’s important to remember the time before the infamous 2017 #MeToo movement.

The actress stars as Cassie in the new BBC drama, which is set in 2006, and while she is obviously one of the top detectives in her workforce, her boss is seen mocking his employee for her gender.

‘If I wanted you to stand there looking pretty, I’d have hired someone with bigger t**s,’ he shouts at her across his office, before Cassie is told she was only hired to fill the quota.

But while the abuse might seem rather startling to viewers, the star insisted it was important not to forget that world existed.

She told Metro.co.uk: ‘It’s funny because it’s set in a time before the #MeToo movement in 2006, so you know I don’t think if it was set today those comments would have been written or made, but it was a different world back then.

‘Of course, it’s important to play a strong woman, but it’s also important to show that world – and let’s not forget that it existed.’

Cassie’s boss is seen mocking his employee for her gender (Picture: BBC)

She is told she was only hired to fill the quota (Picture: BBC)

Opening up on her character, Sarah added: ‘But yeah Cassie is well able.

‘She’s also worked really hard. She is who she is, she’s also really young and there’s a line that she just got the job because they’re filling quotas. So she is just like “water off a duck’s back,” you know?’

The Irish actress went on: ‘”I’m good at my job and you’re all f***ing jealous,” is kind of her mindset I think.’

Sarah stars alongside Killian Scott who plays her partner detective Rob.

She said of the pair: ‘They’re the top two detectives on the scene, and probably the youngest.

The show sees detectives Rob Reilly and Cassie Madox take on a child murder (Picture: BBC)

‘Cassie is undercover, and that was her dream, and that’s what she wanted, so she was very driven and didn’t give up. She is living her dream.’

Dublin Murders debuted just yesterday and sees homicide detectives Rob Reilly and Cassie Madox take on a child murder.

After being dispatched, the pair discover a body of a teenage girl placed on an altar in the middle of an archaeological site.

But this isn’t the first time a teen has been discovered in the same location, as three children in the 80s were wrapped up in a murder investigation, seeing only one of them survive.

The police and press alike are worried that the two are connected, and it seems Rob is holding onto more secrets about his past than we might have first thought.

Dublin Murders airs tonight on BBC One at 9pm.
